results.question: What costs are associated under capital expenditure?
gold_answer: associated with acquiring property, plant and equipment and placing it into service
results.markdown_table_response:
Capital expenditures are a significant and material component of our cash flows and free cash flow. They are used to fund our business operations and strategic investments. They also reflect the value of our real estate.
We measure capital intensity by comparing the percentage change in our capital expenditures to our free cash flow. We do not include the change in our capital expenditures in the calculation of our free cash flow, as this is not a measure that investors use and can be misleading to investors and analysts.
results.csv_string_response: Capital expenditures are costs associated with the acquisition of property, plant and equipment and placing it into service. The telecommunications business requires extensive and continual investments, including investment in new technologies and the expansion of capacity and geographical reach. Expenditures related to the acquisition of spectrum licences and additions to right-of-use assets are not included in capital expenditures and do not factor into the calculation of free cash flow or capital intensity. See “Managing Our Liquidity and Financial Resources”, “Key Performance Indicators”, and “Non-GAAP Measures and Related Performance Measures” for more information.
results.json_rows_response: Capital expenditure is not a financial measure. It is a measure of spending in the telecommunications industry. It does not include spectrum licences and additions to right-of-use assets.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response:
EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.

results.question: When is revenue recognized?
gold_answer: Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer.
results.csv_string_response: The Company recognizes revenue upon the achievement of the revenue-based milestones and upon the performance of the license and collaboration agreements. Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. When determining the transaction price of the contract, an adjustment is made if payment from a customer occurs either significantly before or significantly after performance, resulting in a significant financing component. None of the Company’s licenses and collaboration agreements contained a significant financing component at either December 31, 2019 or 2018.
results.json_rows_response: It's dependent on when the milestone is reached and when payment is received.

• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018
